Author: Slyris#2880
Content: But to be honest you have to be careful, cgo does not keep all its promises in golang and disables the most interesting features of languages

Author: Slyris#2880
Content: @grewalsatinder Yeah it's was i mean

Author: Slyris#2880
Content: For example a super interesting thing in golang is the cross building, it is disabled with the use of cgo, ie no android, no ios and if unix system functions, no windows anymore...

Author: grewalsatinder#9653
Content:

Content: okay mate. thanks for giving me some direction. üëç

Author: Slyris#2880
Content: In fact if you want, what would be great is to have the strict equivalent of libnspv written entirely in golang, the problem is that it would require double maintenance. By that it should follow the updates of libnspv in C of jl777 and reproducires without error in golang. Not worth.

Author: grewalsatinder#9653
Content: agree

Author: Slyris#2880
Content: I am personally working on a nspv system in C++. My program downloads the latest version of nspv according to the platform, starts the process and communicates in rpc with.

Author: grewalsatinder#9653
Content:
I can also make a go code using libnspv's rpc, can indeed also go for making gRPC for libnspv.
but that would mean running the `./nspv` binary and using it's RPC API calls.

Author: Slyris#2880
Content:
I discussed it with @ca333 yesterday in DM, that's not a good idea because it's add an external layers.

He is right to say that every langage have now great http library to communicate with rpc binaries

Author: grewalsatinder#9653
Content: yep, true that

Author: Slyris#2880
Content: Even i agree too that gRPC api is more easy to use than raw http stuff

Author: Slyris#2880
Content: Because in this way You download a Golang microservices that download nspv and start the process make 2 process for just calling rpc stuff

Author: Slyris#2880
Content: It's a performance penalty
